data.title: ExxonMobil targets $3B earnings contribution from 2025 project start-ups amid record Guyana and Permian output
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Exxon Mobil Corporation (XOM) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Darren Woods, Chairman of the Board, President & CEO, emphasized, "From the technologies we're deploying to the major projects we're delivering to the structural cost savings we're capturing and the value we're creating, our results are truly in a league of their own." Woods highlighted record-breaking production in Guyana, exceeding 700,000 barrels per day and the early launch of Yellowtail, the company's fourth and largest Guyana development, which came online four months ahead of schedule with a 250,000 barrels per day capacity.

  • Woods noted the sanctioning of the Hammerhead project in Guyana, expected to begin production in 2029, and emphasized the growing local impact, citing more than 6,000 Guyanese workers and over 2,000 local businesses engaged.

  • In the Permian Basin, ExxonMobil achieved a production record of nearly 1.7 million oil-equivalent barrels per day and acquired over 80,000 net acres in the Midland Basin from Sinochem Petroleum, aiming to "drive greater returns" through technology deployment.

  • Woods discussed the rollout of ExxonMobil’s lightweight proppant, stating, "Our proprietary proppant is delivering significant improvements in resource recovery...supporting our own results." Approximately 25% of wells are expected to use this patented proppant in 2025, rising to 50% by the end of 2026.

  • Woods described progress in Product Solutions, mentioning a tripling of Proxxima systems production and the introduction of new products like Proxxima-based rebar and a one-coat marine cargo tank solution. He also highlighted the acquisition of key assets from Superior Graphite and the commissioning of Discovery 6, a supercomputer aiding seismic processing in Guyana.

  • Kathryn Mikells, Senior VP & CFO, stated, "We had an acquisition, actually a couple of acquisitions this quarter in total $2.4 billion...We expect to be a bit below the low end of the $27 billion to $29 billion cash CapEx, that's excluding those M&A transactions."

Outlook

  • Woods confirmed continued investment in innovation and technology, with plans to share further updates on the Permian at the December corporate plan update. Management expects about a quarter of 2025 wells to use the new proppant, with roughly half by late 2026. Woods projected, "These 10 projects establish an important foundation to our 2030 earnings and cash flow growth plans. They're expected to drive more than $3 billion in earnings contributions next year at constant prices and margin."

  • Management noted capital expenditure will be below the previously guided $27 billion to $29 billion range, excluding acquisitions, pacing spend in line with market development, especially in low carbon solutions due to slower-than-expected market evolution.

Financial Results

  • ExxonMobil reported record production in both Guyana and the Permian Basin. The company acquired assets totaling $2.4 billion during the quarter. Utilization of the Singapore Resid Upgrade project reached 80%, targeting full capacity by year-end. Woods said, "We saw the highest reliability that we've ever had" in refining, attributing this to their centralized operations organization.

Q&A

  • Neil Mehta, Goldman Sachs: Questioned drivers behind capital spend being below guidance. Woods responded that pacing is consistent with market development, especially in new ventures and low carbon solutions, as those markets develop slower than anticipated. Mikells clarified acquisitions are excluded from CapEx guidance.

  • Devin McDermott, Morgan Stanley: Asked about Permian drivers and technology impact. Woods explained improvements stem from ongoing innovation and technology deployment, with productivity gains and capital efficiency highlighted.

  • Arun Jayaram, JPMorgan: Inquired about Exxon’s long-term energy outlook informing strategy. Woods explained the global outlook forms the foundation for strategic planning, focusing on long-term fundamentals and recognizing the need for continuous investment to offset depletion rates.

  • Douglas George Blyth Leggate, Wolfe Research: Pressed on dividend growth. Mikells stated, "We look at our overall dividend growth rate, and we constantly think about sustainability...we feel pretty happy with where we've ended up."

  • Bob Brackett, Sanford C. Bernstein: Sought details on the Superior Graphite acquisition. Woods described plans for a differentiated graphitization process, expecting to develop lower-cost battery anode materials, targeting a total addressable market up to $40 billion.

  • Questions also addressed inorganic growth opportunities, organizational capability versus opportunity set, Mozambique project progress, exploration focus, technology adoption in downstream, and refining margin outlook.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts raised forward-looking questions on capital allocation, technology deployment, and dividend policy, with a generally neutral to slightly positive tone. Multiple analysts pressed for clarity on capital spend, technology impact, and dividend growth.

  • Management maintained a confident and optimistic tone, particularly in prepared remarks, emphasizing execution, technology, and capital discipline. Woods repeatedly used confident phrases such as "we feel good about the progress we're making" and "I'm confident we will remain in a league of our own."

  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s tone remained consistently confident, with analysts maintaining a focus on execution and capital return.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance language shifted to emphasize more dynamic capital allocation, with spend paced to market development, particularly in low carbon solutions. In contrast to Q2, management gave a more detailed update on technology deployment and project timelines in Guyana and Permian.

  • Analysts continued to focus on CapEx discipline, technology’s role in growth, and capital returns, mirroring themes from the prior quarter.

  • Key metric changes included new records in Guyana and Permian production, new asset acquisitions, and the introduction of advanced proppant technologies. Management’s confidence and focus on long-term value creation remained unchanged.

Risks and Concerns

  • Woods noted that some low carbon solutions markets are not developing as quickly as expected, resulting in paced investment. He highlighted, "We're pacing the spend...as we see the demand for some of those products grow."

  • Management acknowledged uncertainty in capital project timing due to market and policy development. Risks related to the broader macro environment and technology adoption timelines were also discussed.

Final Takeaway

ExxonMobil management highlighted record production achievements in Guyana and the Permian and outlined the company’s strengthened position through technology deployment, project execution, and disciplined capital allocation. Leaders projected significant earnings contributions from 2025 project start-ups and emphasized the company’s long-term focus, resilience, and ability to deliver value through both innovation and scale, while remaining responsive to evolving market opportunities and risks.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: TerraVest Industries appoints new CFO
data.description:
• TerraVest Industries (TVK:CA) announced the appointment of Guillaume Cloutier as chief financial officer.  

  • Cloutier assumes the CFO role from Marilyn Boucher.

  • Cloutier has held senior leadership positions in several industry-leading manufacturing businesses across North America.

data.title: Imperial Metals repays all outstanding senior unsecured non-convertible debentures
data.description:
• Imperial Metals (III:CA) has fully repaid all outstanding senior unsecured non-convertible debentures due November 1, 2025.
  • The Company has repaid the principal amount of $34.47M, along with accrued interest, under the senior unsecured non-convertible debentures issued by the Company on June 30, 2023, and amended in June 2024.
  • The 2023 Debentures carried an interest rate of 12.0% per annum.
  • Additionally, the company has repaid the principal amount of $45M, along with accrued interest, under the senior unsecured non-convertible debentures issued by the Company on March 1, 2024.
  • The 2024 debentures also carried an interest rate of 12% per annum.

data.title: Gold slides as investors slash December rate cut bets
data.description:
Gold futures finished lower Friday, weighed by uncertainty over another U.S. interest rate cut this year, but a nearly 3.5% loss this week was not enough to prevent a third straight positive monthly performance in October.

Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland President Beth Hammack said Friday that she opposes more rate cuts - becoming the third regional Fed president to publicly oppose further cuts - and that the Fed needs to maintain some restriction to bring down inflation.

Hammack will be an FOMC voter in 2026, and analysts say her hawkish comments show the market was too optimistic in pricing lower rates.

The Fed cut rates on Wednesday, but remarks from Chair Powell that a reduction at the December policy meeting is "not a forgone conclusion - far from it" mean markets are now pricing a 63% chance of another cut this year, down from more than 90% earlier this week, according to the CME FedWatch tool.

"We expect gold prices to remain elevated in the coming weeks, especially as central bank purchases remain high," BMI analysts said in a note, but "risks are slated to the downside as the Fed has downplayed the possibility of another cut in December and the trade deal between the U.S. and China has abated a lot of the uncertainty in the market."

Morgan Stanley said gold prices could climb to $4,500/oz by mid-2026, citing strong physical demand by ETFs and central banks as the economic outlook remains uncertain.

"Recent price action took gold well into 'overbought' territory on a [Relative Strength Index] basis, but the recent correction has taken it to a healthier level, likely cleaning up positioning," Morgan Stanley wrote.

Front-month Comex gold (XAUUSD:CUR) for November delivery closed -0.5% on Friday to $3,982.20/oz, and front-month Comex November silver (XAGUSD:CUR) ended -0.9% to $47.994/oz; for the month of October, gold and silver both gained 3.7%, overcoming respective losses of 3.4% and 0.8% this week.

ETFs: (GLD), (GDX), (GDXJ), (IAU), (NUGT), (PHYS), (GLDM), (AAAU), (SGOL), (RING), (BAR), (OUNZ), (SLV), (PSLV), (SIVR), (SIL), (SILJ)

data.title: PriceSmart outlines three new club openings and continues digital growth with 21.6% e-commerce sales increase
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: PriceSmart (PSMT) Q4 2025

Management View

  • David Price, CEO, introduced himself and CFO Gualberto Hernandez as new leaders, stating, “We're settling in well and energized by the opportunities ahead.” He expressed appreciation for Robert Price, the Executive Chairman, and highlighted a “productive, positive and collaborative relationship.”
  • Price announced the move to a new corporate headquarters in San Diego, describing it as "a meaningful step forward, providing us space designed to foster the kind of culture and ways of working that will support our people and mission for years to come."
  • Key real estate expansions include the opening of the seventh warehouse club in Guatemala, land purchases for new clubs in the Dominican Republic and Jamaica, and a land lease for an additional Jamaican club. Price said, “Once these 3 new clubs are open, we will operate 59 warehouse clubs in total.”
  • On international expansion, Price confirmed progress in Chile: “As part of this initiative, we've hired a country general manager and signed an executory agreement for a prospective club site.”
  • Supply chain transformation remains central. Price noted the opening of a new dry distribution center in Guatemala, adaptation of the Panama facility for cold merchandise, and plans for PriceSmart-run distribution centers in Trinidad and the Dominican Republic in fiscal 2026.
  • Digital investment is a focus, with Price reporting, “Digital channel sales reached $306.7 million in fiscal year 2025, up 21.6% year-over-year and represented 6% of total net merchandise sales.” New digital and point-of-sale system rollouts are planned, along with a migration to a native mobile app architecture.
  • Private label penetration rose to 28.1% of merchandise sales, and a new co-branded credit card with Banco Credomatic BAC was launched in Central America, offering “higher cash back rewards.”
  • Platinum membership penetration increased to 17.9% of the total base, and renewal rates held at 88.8%.
  • CFO Gualberto Hernandez stated, “Total gross margin as a percentage of net merchandise sales for the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2025 remained unchanged at 15.7% when compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2024.”

Outlook

  • PriceSmart plans to open three new clubs in fiscal 2026, including two in Jamaica and one in the Dominican Republic, with a prospective entry into Chile pending permitting and construction progress.
  • Digital and technology investments are set to accelerate, including full implementation of the RELEX supply chain platform in 2026 and a new point-of-sale system rollout.
  • No explicit update to revenue or EPS guidance was given.

Financial Results

  • Net merchandise sales and total revenue for the fourth quarter were both reported as over $1.3 billion. Net merchandise sales increased by 9.2%.
  • For the fiscal year ended August 31, 2025, total net merchandise sales reached almost $5.2 billion and total revenues were almost $5.3 billion. Net merchandise sales for the year increased by 7.7%.
  • Operating income for the quarter rose to $52.8 million, and net income was $31.5 million or $1.02 per diluted share.
  • Adjusted EBITDA for the quarter was $75.5 million.
  • Cash, cash equivalents, and restricted cash ended the quarter at $285.3 million, with $73.2 million in short-term investments.
  • Membership income in the quarter reached $22.6 million, a 14.9% increase over the prior year period.

Q&A

  • Jon Braatz, Kansas City Capital Associates, asked whether Jamaican clubs sustained damage from Hurricane Melissa. Price confirmed, "Yes. So regarding our clubs in Jamaica, they were not damaged."
  • Braatz also asked if the South Camp club in Jamaica would be smaller due to acreage. Price replied, “That's not the intention. We're going to have to do some changes in our parking format… but the intention is to have a typical size club there.”
  • Héctor Maya López, Scotiabank, inquired about Chilean expansion timing. Price responded, “We have not provided opening date information at this point. So that's all I can share with you.”
  • López questioned EBITDA margin methodology changes. Hernandez said, “There were no changes in the methodology. And as you know, we don't disclose details on this. But I can tell you that we have not seen any material mix changes that would impact EBITDA.”
  • Braatz asked about the impact of changes in U.S. remittances to certain countries. Price stated, “We have no indication so far a slowdown that's impacted consumption that we can see.”

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts maintained a neutral tone, posing factual questions about operational impacts from weather, expansion plans, and financial methodology. No skepticism or pressing was evident.
  • Management’s tone was positive and confident, especially in their outlook on expansion, supply chain upgrades, and digital transformation. CEO Price described himself as “incredibly optimistic about the future of PriceSmart.”
  • Compared to the previous quarter, analyst sentiment remained neutral, while management confidence appeared to increase, particularly with the new leadership team and strategic initiatives underway.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Management transitions to CEO David Price and CFO Gualberto Hernandez were completed, compared to outgoing leadership in Q3.
  • The previous quarter emphasized Chile as an opportunity under evaluation; this quarter detailed a signed executory agreement and a country general manager hire for Chile.
  • Private label penetration rose from 27.7% to 28.1% of sales, and digital channel sales growth accelerated from 19.8% in Q3 to 21.6% for the fiscal year.
  • Platinum membership continued to rise, now at 17.9% up from 16.1%.
  • Membership renewal remained high, with a slight increase from 88% to 88.8%.
  • Management’s tone shifted from cautious optimism to pronounced confidence, reflecting the new leadership’s forward-looking stance.

Risks and Concerns

  • Price addressed the operational impact of Hurricane Melissa, confirming temporary club closures in Jamaica but no lasting damage.
  • The company cited ongoing challenges in converting local currency in Trinidad and is monitoring U.S. dollar liquidity in Honduras.
  • Price acknowledged potential risks from changes in remittance flows to key markets but reported no current impact.
  • Technology investments contributed to higher SG&A expenses, with $600,000 in the quarter related to growth initiatives and $700,000 in CFO transition costs.

Final Takeaway

The company closed fiscal 2025 with strong sales growth, successful leadership transition, and robust expansion plans, including three new club openings and ongoing preparation for Chilean market entry. Digital and private label initiatives continue to gain traction, while operational resilience was demonstrated during recent storms. Management is optimistic about delivering further value to members and shareholders in fiscal 2026, with technology and supply chain upgrades positioned as key growth drivers.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Canoe Mining Ventures launches $400,000 private placement
data.description:
• Canoe Mining Ventures (CLV:CA) said on Friday that it intends to complete a non-brokered private placement through the issuance of up to 8M units in the capital of the company at a price of $0.05 per unit, for total gross proceeds of up to $575,000.
  • Each unit will consist of one common share in the capital of the company and one-half of one common share purchase warrant. Each warrant will entitle the holder thereof to purchase one common share at a price of $0.08 per common share until the date that is thirty-six (36) months from the date of issuance.
  • The company intends to use the net proceeds from the Offering to acquire and evaluate new mineral exploration properties, advance existing projects, and for general working capital and corporate purposes.
  • Source: Press Release

data.title: Middlesex Water GAAP EPS of $0.77 misses by $0.10, revenue of $54.09M misses by $1.99M
data.description:
• Middlesex Water press release (MSEX): Q3 GAAP EPS of $0.77 misses by $0.10.
  • Revenue of $54.09M (-1.8% Y/Y) misses by $1.99M.

data.title: J&J submits application to FDA for expanded use of Stelara
data.description:
• Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) has submitted a new application to the U.S. FDA to expand the use of Stelara (ustekinumab) for treating children aged two and older with moderate to severe ulcerative colitis.
  • This application is backed by results from the Phase 3 UNIFI Jr clinical trial.
  • Currently, Stelara is approved for adults with moderate to severe Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis, as well as for adults and children aged six and older with active psoriatic arthritis and moderate to severe plaque psoriasis.

data.title: First Business signals 10% annual loan and fee income growth outlook while highlighting record Q3 noninterest income
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: First Business Financial Services, Inc. (FBIZ) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO Corey Chambas stated that First Business delivered another outstanding quarter, highlighting "high-quality loan and deposit growth sourced from core client relationships." Chambas emphasized, "Private Wealth assets continue to expand, delivering significant annuity-like fee income and operating revenue reached record levels, reiterating the value of our revenue diversification." Chambas also noted, "Year-to-date ROA grew 15 basis points to 1.23% compared to the same period of 2024... return on average tangible common equity grew to over 15%, up from just under 14% in 2024. And most importantly for shareholders, we grew tangible book value per share an impressive 16% from a year ago."
  • President and COO David Seiler said, "Third quarter performance was very strong across the board and reflects our consistent growth and profitability. Our model is designed to drive 10% long-term growth." Seiler highlighted, "pretax pre-provision earnings... saw 18% growth from the second quarter and 20% growth compared to the first 9 months of 2024." Seiler also cited "record level of noninterest income generated during the quarter... swap income grew nearly 6x from the linked quarter and income from SBIC funds grew over 4x from the linked quarter."
  • CFO Brian Spielmann confirmed, "Third quarter net interest margin grew 1 basis point to 3.68%, reflecting our continued strong balance sheet management." Spielmann added, "Fees in lieu of interest contributed 23 basis points to margin in Q3, up 5 basis points compared to 18 basis points in Q2." Spielmann projected, "we continue to target a range of 3.60% to 3.65% for margin."

Outlook

  • Management expects annual fee income growth to approximate 10%, with Q4 operating fee income expected to be more in line with the recent 4-quarter average. Brian Spielmann clarified, "If you pull those nonrecurring items out, $77,000 and adjust off of that based off the kind of 4 quarter average, excluding that, that's your good starting point then for 10% growth off of that."
  • The company continues to target loan and deposit growth of 10% and net interest margin in the 3.60% to 3.65% range. Seiler reiterated, "We think there is a really nice opportunity to grow market share and grow those markets for us."

Financial Results

  • Noninterest income reached record levels, including approximately $770,000 from two nonrecurring items: a $537,000 fee from the exit of an accounts receivable finance credit and $234,000 in BOLI insurance proceeds. Swap income grew nearly sixfold from the prior quarter, and SBIC fund income grew more than fourfold.
  • Loan balances grew about $85 million or 10% annualized during the quarter and $286 million or 9% over the same period last year. Core deposits increased 9% from both the linked and prior year quarters, led by large new relationships in South Central Wisconsin.
  • Net charge-offs totaled $1.3 million, primarily from previously reserved equipment finance loans. Nonperforming assets decreased by $5.2 million to 0.58% of total assets, compared to 0.72% last quarter.
  • Compensation expense increased about $900,000 due to an annual cash bonus accrual update, while excluding this, compensation expense declined by about $183,000. The effective tax rate year-to-date was 16.3%.

Q&A

  • Daniel Tamayo, Raymond James: Asked if the 10% fee income guide for next year is adjusted for Q3 nonrecurring items. CFO Spielmann: "I would say it's adjusted for the Q3 items. If you pull those nonrecurring items out... excluding that, that's your good starting point then for 10% growth off of that."
  • Tamayo also questioned margin normalization and deposit cost betas. Spielmann responded, "Our betas on both sides of the balance sheet have historically been pretty consistent, which gives us comfort in the continued message around that 3.60% to 3.65%."
  • Jeff Rulis, D.A. Davidson: Asked about the impact of rate reductions on fees in lieu of interest. Spielmann replied, "The fees in lieu of interest have historically been pretty idiosyncratic... we'll have spikes here and there." CEO Chambas added, "The biggest piece of fee in lieu... comes from our asset-based lending group... those are all floating rate deals."
  • Rulis also asked about capital deployment and acquisition interest. Spielmann detailed, "capital tools we have... common stock dividend increase... $5 million repurchase agreement..." Chambas said, "Capital has continued to build. We're above where we're comfortable with our capital levels."
  • Nathan Race, Piper Sandler: Queried about adjusted margin outlook and growth opportunities. Spielmann said, "stability is the key... 3.4% to 3.45% is going to be our adjusted margin range and expectations."
  • Damon Del Monte, KBW: Questioned investment and wealth management drivers. Chambas indicated growth is "a good mix" of market appreciation and new relationships.
  • Brian Martin, Janney: Asked about funding pressures. Spielmann: "Specific to some CD relationships we brought on at the end of Q2."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts raised clarifying and forward-focused questions regarding fee income sustainability, margin outlook, growth channels, and capital deployment, maintaining a neutral to slightly positive tone.
  • Management's prepared remarks and responses were confident and optimistic, frequently reiterating targets and using language such as "we are very optimistic about the future" (Chambas), while acknowledging competitive and operating challenges.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, the sentiment from both analysts and management remains consistently constructive, with the Q&A in both quarters focusing on growth, margin stability, and credit quality.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance language remained consistent, reiterating 10% annual growth targets for loans and fee income.
  • Strategic focus continues to be on revenue diversification, niche C&I business growth, and talent acquisition.
  • Analysts in both quarters probed on loan growth, margin outlook, and credit quality, with Q3 featuring more discussion about the sustainability of fee income and capital utilization.
  • Management's tone was equally confident in both quarters, but Q3 highlighted the benefits of record noninterest income and improved efficiency, while Q2 focused more on core deposit growth and Private Wealth expansion.
  • Key financial metrics such as tangible book value growth, ROA, and net interest margin showed improvement quarter-over-quarter.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management identified potential timing delays in SBA loan sale premiums due to dependence on federal government processing amid a government shutdown. Seiler stated, "This may affect the already variable timing of SBA loan sale premiums."
  • Competitive deposit pricing and talent acquisition remain ongoing challenges.
  • Nonperforming assets decreased, and management reported no areas of particular concern in the loan portfolio, emphasizing strong underwriting and risk-adjusted returns in niche C&I businesses.

Final Takeaway

First Business Financial Services delivered record noninterest income and robust loan and deposit growth in the third quarter, supporting continued strong profitability and efficiency improvements. Management reiterated confidence in achieving 10% annual growth in loans and fee income, maintaining a stable net interest margin, and building value through disciplined execution and targeted investments in talent and niche businesses. The company remains focused on leveraging its diversified revenue streams and strong capital position to support organic growth and shareholder returns going forward.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Global Engine Group Holding receives Nasdaq minimum bid price deficiency notice
data.description:
• Global Engine Group Holding (NASDAQ:GLE) announced on Friday that it has received a notice from Nasdaq, dated October 27, 2025, stating that the company is not in compliance with a minimum bid price of $1 per share as set forth under Nasdaq Listing Rule 5550(a)(2).
  • Nasdaq Listing Rule 5810(c)(3)(A) provides that a failure to meet the minimum bid price requirement exists if the deficiency continues for a period of 30 consecutive business days.
  • The company’s shares must be at least $1.00 per share for a minimum of 10 consecutive business days at any time before the expiration of the compliance period to regain compliance with the minimum bid rule.
  • However, the notice has no immediate effect on the listing of the company’s shares, which will continue to trade on the Nasdaq Capital Market under the symbol “GLE.”
  • The company plans to evaluate options to regain compliance with the minimum bid price rule by effecting a reverse stock split, if nedeed.
